sols_html:
By the integral test, this sum is convergent if and only if the integral

\[\begin{aligned} \int_2^\infty \left(\frac{1}{\ln x}\right)^2 \frac{1}{x} \, dx\end{aligned}\]

is also convergent. Using the substitution \(u=\ln x\),

\[\begin{aligned} &\int_2^\infty \left(\frac{1}{\ln x}\right)^2 \frac{1}{x} \, dx \\ &= \lim_{b \rightarrow \infty} \int_2^b \left(\frac{1}{\ln x}\right)^2 \frac{1}{x} \, dx \\ &= \lim_{b \rightarrow \infty} \int_{\ln2}^{\ln b} \frac{1}{u^2} \, du\\ &= \lim_{b \rightarrow \infty} \left.-\frac{1}{u} \right|_{\ln2}^{\ln b}\\ &= \lim_{b \rightarrow \infty} \left(-\frac{1}{\ln b} + \frac{1}{\ln 2}\right)\\ &= \frac{1}{\ln2} <\infty.\end{aligned}\]

Hence, the sum is convergent.
